sections.title: Theorems of perpendicular and parallel axes
sections.description: Theorems used to calculate the moment of inertia about various axes based on known values.

content.introduction: Calculating $I$ from scratch using integration is difficult. Two powerful theorems allow us to calculate $I$ about new axes using known values.

coreConcepts.explanation: The moment of inertia $I_z$ of a body about any axis is equal to its moment of inertia about a parallel axis passing through the center of mass ($I_{cm}$) plus the product of the mass and the square of the distance $d$ between the axes: $$I_z = I_{cm} + Md^2$$.
coreConcepts.example: I of a rod about one end: $I_{end} = I_{cm} + M(L/2)^2 = \frac{ML^2}{12} + \frac{ML^2}{4} = \frac{ML^2}{3}$.

coreConcepts.explanation: Applicable only to **planar bodies** (laminar). The moment of inertia about an axis perpendicular to the plane ($I_z$) is the sum of moments of inertia about two perpendicular axes ($I_x, I_y$) lying in the plane and intersecting at the point where the z-axis passes: $$I_z = I_x + I_y$$.
coreConcepts.example: Disc: $I_z = MR^2/2$. By symmetry $I_x = I_y$ (diameters). $2I_{dia} = MR^2/2 \implies I_{dia} = MR^2/4$.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: A flat lamina in x-y plane with z axis sticking up.

summary: Parallel axis theorem works for any 3D body.
Perpendicular axis theorem works ONLY for 2D plane laminas.

content.introduction: The description of rotation with constant angular acceleration is mathematically identical to linear motion with constant acceleration.

Where $\theta$ is angular displacement.

sections.description: Analysis of rolling as a combination of translational motion of the center of mass and rotational motion about the center of mass.

content.introduction: Rolling is the most common combination of translation and rotation. When a wheel rolls without slipping, there is a precise link between linear and angular velocity.

coreConcepts.explanation: For rolling without slipping, the point of contact with the ground is instantaneously at rest. This implies $v_{cm} = R\omega$ and $a_{cm} = R\alpha$.
coreConcepts.example: A car tire moving at 60mph: the bottom touches the road at 0 speed relative to the road, the top moves at 120mph.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: Wheel showing velocity vectors at top (2v), center (v), and bottom (0).

coreConcepts.explanation: Total Kinetic Energy is the sum of translational and rotational energies: $$K = K_{trans} + K_{rot} = \frac{1}{2}Mv_{cm}^2 + \frac{1}{2}I_{cm}\omega^2$$. Using $v=R\omega$, this can be written as $K = \frac{1}{2}Mv^2(1 + \frac{k^2}{R^2})$ where k is radius of gyration.
coreConcepts.example: A rolling ball has more energy than a sliding block at the same speed because of the rotation.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: Energy equation breakdown.

summary: Rolling = Translation + Rotation.
Friction is required to initiate rolling but does no work in pure rolling.
Objects with lower I/MR^2 roll faster down a hill.

sections.title: Introduction
sections.description: An overview of the historical development of planetary motion theories and the concept of gravity.

content.introduction: The understanding of planetary motion has evolved significantly over human history. Early models placed the Earth at the center of the universe, a view that persisted for centuries until observational data demanded a paradigm shift to a sun-centered model.

coreConcepts.explanation: Ptolemy proposed the **geocentric model**, where celestial bodies revolved around a stationary Earth. This was challenged by Copernicus, who proposed the **heliocentric model**, placing the Sun at the center. Galileo's telescopic observations of Jupiter's moons and Venus's phases provided critical evidence supporting the heliocentric theory.
coreConcepts.example: The retrograde motion of Mars (apparent backward motion) was difficult to explain geocentrically but naturally explained by Earth 'overtaking' Mars in the heliocentric model.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: A comparison diagram showing the complex epicycles of the Ptolemaic system versus the simpler concentric orbits of the Copernican system.

coreConcepts.explanation: Before Newton, the motion of planets and the falling of objects on Earth were seen as separate phenomena. Newton realized that the force causing an apple to fall is the same force keeping the Moon in orbit. This unification is the foundation of the universal law of gravitation.
coreConcepts.example: Newton compared the acceleration of the Moon to the acceleration of a falling object on Earth, finding they followed an inverse-square relationship with distance.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: Illustration of Newton's thought experiment: a cannonball fired from a mountain top with increasing speed until it enters orbit.

summary: The heliocentric model replaced the geocentric model based on better observational evidence.
Gravity is a universal force that acts between all masses, not just on Earth.

sections.title: Keplers laws
sections.description: Examination of the three laws describing the motion of planets around the sun.

content.introduction: Johannes Kepler analyzed the precise data collected by Tycho Brahe to formulate three empirical laws that describe how planets move around the Sun. These laws laid the groundwork for Newton's gravitational theory.

coreConcepts.explanation: All planets move in elliptical orbits with the Sun situated at one of the foci of the ellipse. An ellipse is defined by two focal points; the sum of the distances from any point on the curve to the two foci is constant.
coreConcepts.example: Earth's orbit is an ellipse, meaning the distance between Earth and Sun changes throughout the year (Perihelion vs Aphelion).
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: An ellipse showing the major axis, minor axis, and the Sun at one focus.

coreConcepts.explanation: The line that joins any planet to the sun sweeps out equal areas in equal intervals of time. Mathematically, $\frac{dA}{dt} = \text{constant}$. This implies that the planet moves faster when it is closer to the Sun and slower when it is farther away, conserving angular momentum.
coreConcepts.example: A planet covers a larger arc length near perihelion (closest approach) than at aphelion (farthest point) in the same amount of time.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: A diagram of an orbit with two shaded sectors of equal area, showing different arc lengths.

coreConcepts.explanation: The square of the time period of revolution of a planet is proportional to the cube of the semi-major axis of the ellipse traced out by the planet. Formula: $T^2 \propto a^3$ or $\frac{T^2}{a^3} = \text{constant}$.
coreConcepts.example: Jupiter is farther from the Sun than Earth ($a_{J} > a_{E}$), so its orbital period is much longer ($T_{J} > T_{E}$).
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: Graph of $T^2$ vs $a^3$ for different planets, showing a straight line.

summary: Orbits are elliptical, not circular.
Planetary speed varies with distance from the Sun (Law of Areas).
$T^2$ is proportional to $a^3$.

content.introduction: Newton synthesized the work of Kepler and Galileo into a single mathematical law describing the attractive force between any two masses in the universe.

coreConcepts.explanation: Every particle of matter attracts every other particle with a force directly proportional to the product of their masses and inversely proportional to the square of the distance between them. Formula: $F = G \frac{m_1 m_2}{r^2}$, where $G$ is the universal gravitational constant.
coreConcepts.example: If you double the mass of one object, the force doubles. If you double the distance between them, the force becomes one-fourth ($1/2^2$) of the original.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: Two masses $m_1$ and $m_2$ separated by distance $r$, with force vectors pointing toward each other.

coreConcepts.explanation: Gravitational force is a vector quantity acting along the line joining the masses. In vector notation: $\vec{F}_{12} = -G \frac{m_1 m_2}{r^2} \hat{r}_{12}$. The negative sign indicates the force is attractive (pointing opposite to the radial vector pointing outwards).
coreConcepts.example: The force exerted by Earth on the Moon is equal in magnitude and opposite in direction to the force exerted by the Moon on Earth (Newton's 3rd Law).
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: Vector diagram showing $\vec{F}_{12}$ and $\vec{F}_{21}$.

summary: Gravity is always attractive.
It follows an inverse-square law ($1/r^2$).
The force is mutual and equal on both bodies.

content.introduction: The universal gravitational constant, $G$, is a fundamental physical constant appearing in Newton's law of gravitation. It represents the strength of gravity in the universe.

coreConcepts.explanation: $G$ is the force of attraction between two unit masses separated by a unit distance. Its accepted value is approximately $6.674 \times 10^{-11} \text{ N m}^2 \text{kg}^{-2}$. It is a scalar quantity.
coreConcepts.example: Because $G$ is so small, the gravitational force between everyday objects (like two people) is negligible compared to Earth's pull.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: Equation graphic: $G = \frac{Fr^2}{m_1 m_2}$.

coreConcepts.explanation: Henry Cavendish performed the first experiment to measure $G$ using a sensitive torsion balance. He measured the tiny twist in a wire caused by the gravitational attraction between lead spheres. This was effectively 'weighing the Earth'.
coreConcepts.example: By determining $G$, Cavendish could calculate the mass of the Earth using $g = \frac{GM}{R^2}$.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: Schematic of the Cavendish torsion balance with large lead spheres attracting small spheres on a rod.

summary: $G$ is a universal constant, unlike $g$ which varies by location.
The value of $G$ is extremely small, indicating gravity is a weak force.

questions.question: What are the dimensional formula for the universal gravitational constant G?
If the units of mass, length, and time are doubled, what happens to the numerical value of G?
questions.explanation: Unit of G is $N m^2 / kg^2$ or $m^3 / (kg \cdot s^2)$. If units double: $L' = 2L, M' = 2M, T' = 2T$. The new unit factor is $(2)^3 / (2 \cdot 2^2) = 8 / 8 = 1$. Wait, let's re-evaluate dimensions $[M^{-1}L^3T^{-2}]$. Factor is $(2)^{-1}(2)^3(2)^{-2} = (1/2)(8)(1/4) = 1$. The physical quantity is constant, but if we change the size of the units, the numerical value changes inversely. Actually, checking the math: $2^{-1} * 2^3 * 2^{-2} = 2^0 = 1$. The numerical value remains the same.

sections.title: Acceleration due to gravity of the earth
sections.description: Analysis of the acceleration experienced by objects near the Earth's surface.

content.introduction: Objects fall towards Earth with an acceleration denoted by $g$. This acceleration is derived from Newton's Universal Law applied to the Earth and an object on its surface.

coreConcepts.explanation: For an object of mass $m$ on Earth's surface (Mass $M$, Radius $R$), the gravitational force is $F = \frac{GMm}{R^2}$. By Newton's 2nd Law, $F = mg$. Equating them: $mg = \frac{GMm}{R^2} \implies g = \frac{GM}{R^2}$.
coreConcepts.example: This equation shows that $g$ is independent of the mass of the falling object ($m$), explaining Galileo's observation that all objects fall at the same rate in a vacuum.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: Diagram showing Earth with Radius $R$ and a small mass $m$ on the surface.

coreConcepts.explanation: Plugging in Earth's mass ($6 \times 10^{24}$ kg) and radius ($6.4 \times 10^6$ m), we get $g \approx 9.8 \text{ m/s}^2$. This value varies slightly due to Earth's non-spherical shape (oblate spheroid) and rotation.
coreConcepts.example: $g$ is slightly higher at the poles (smaller $R$) than at the equator (larger $R$).
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: Earth showing different radii at equator and poles.

microsections.title: Variation of g with Height and Depth

content.introduction: The value of $g$ is maximum at the Earth's surface. It decreases whether you go up into space or down into the Earth.

coreConcepts.explanation: At height $h$ above the surface, $g_h = \frac{GM}{(R+h)^2} = g(\frac{R}{R+h})^2$. For small heights ($h \ll R$), we use the binomial approximation: $g_h \approx g(1 - \frac{2h}{R})$.
coreConcepts.example: At the top of Mount Everest ($h \approx 8.8$ km), $g$ is slightly less than at sea level.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: Graph showing $g$ decreasing as $1/r^2$ for $r > R$.

coreConcepts.explanation: At depth $d$ below the surface, only the inner sphere of radius $(R-d)$ contributes to gravity (Shell Theorem). The formula is $g_d = g(1 - \frac{d}{R})$.
coreConcepts.example: At the center of the Earth ($d=R$), the acceleration due to gravity is zero.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: Graph showing $g$ decreasing linearly to zero as $r$ goes from $R$ to 0.

summary: $g$ decreases with height (inverse square).
$g$ decreases with depth (linearly).
$g$ is zero at Earth's center.

sections.title: Gravitational potential energy
sections.description: Study of the energy associated with the position of a mass in a gravitational field.

content.introduction: Gravitational potential energy ($U$) is the energy possessed by a body due to its position in a gravitational field. Unlike the local approximation $mgh$, the universal formula accounts for the varying force of gravity.

coreConcepts.explanation: Gravitational potential energy is defined as the work done in bringing a mass $m$ from infinity to a point at distance $r$ from mass $M$. The formula is $U = -\frac{GMm}{r}$.
coreConcepts.example: The value is always negative because the gravitational force is attractive; work is done *by* the field to bring the mass in, or work must be done *against* the field to move it to infinity (where $U=0$).
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: Plot of Potential Energy vs Distance $r$, showing the curve approaching zero from the negative side as $r \to \infty$.

coreConcepts.explanation: Gravitational potential is the potential energy per unit mass: $V = \frac{U}{m} = -\frac{GM}{r}$. It is a scalar property of the location in the field.
coreConcepts.example: All points at the same distance from the Earth have the same gravitational potential.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: Equipotential surfaces (concentric spheres) around a mass.

summary: $U = -\frac{GMm}{r}$.

questions.question: Calculate the work done to move a body of mass $m$ from an orbit of radius $2R$ to $3R$ around Earth (mass $M$).
questions.explanation: Work = Change in PE = $U_f - U_i$. $U_f = -\frac{GMm}{3R}$, $U_i = -\frac{GMm}{2R}$. Work = $(-\frac{GMm}{3R}) - (-\frac{GMm}{2R}) = \frac{GMm}{R}(\frac{1}{2} - \frac{1}{3}) = \frac{GMm}{6R}$.

questions.question: Two masses $m$ are separated by distance $r$. What is the work required to double the separation distance?
questions.explanation: $W = U_{final} - U_{initial} = -\frac{Gmm}{2r} - (-\frac{Gmm}{r}) = \frac{Gm^2}{r}(1 - 0.5) = \frac{Gm^2}{2r}$.

sections.title: Escape speed
sections.description: The minimum speed required for an object to break free from a gravitational field.

content.introduction: If you throw a ball up, it comes down. If you throw it faster, it goes higher. Is there a speed at which it never comes back? This is the escape speed.

coreConcepts.explanation: To escape, the object must reach infinity with at least zero kinetic energy. Initial Energy ($KE+PE$) = Final Energy (0). $\frac{1}{2}mv_e^2 - \frac{GMm}{R} = 0$. Solving for $v_e$: $v_e = \sqrt{\frac{2GM}{R}}$.
coreConcepts.example: Alternatively, using surface gravity $g$: $v_e = \sqrt{2gR}$.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: Rocket trajectory leaving Earth and not returning.

coreConcepts.explanation: Escape speed depends on the mass and radius of the planet ($M, R$) but is **independent** of the mass of the projectile ($m$) and the angle of projection (as long as it doesn't hit the ground).
coreConcepts.example: For Earth, $v_e \approx 11.2 \text{ km/s}$. For the Moon, it is much lower (approx $2.4 \text{ km/s}$), which is why the Moon cannot hold an atmosphere.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: Comparison of escape velocities for Earth, Moon, and Jupiter.

summary: $v_e = \sqrt{\frac{2GM}{R}}$

Approx 11.2 km/s for Earth.

sections.title: Earth satellite
sections.description: Principles governing the motion of artificial and natural satellites orbiting Earth.

content.introduction: Satellites are objects that revolve around a planet. Their motion is governed by the balance between gravitational pull and the inertia of their forward motion.

coreConcepts.explanation: The velocity required to put a satellite into orbit around the earth. The centripetal force is provided by gravity: $\frac{mv_o^2}{r} = \frac{GMm}{r^2}$. Thus, $v_o = \sqrt{\frac{GM}{r}}$.
coreConcepts.example: For a satellite close to Earth ($r \approx R$), $v_o \approx 8 \text{ km/s}$.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: Forces acting on a satellite in circular orbit.

coreConcepts.explanation: The time taken to complete one revolution. $T = \frac{\text{Circumference}}{\text{Velocity}} = \frac{2\pi r}{v_o}$. Substituting $v_o$: $T = 2\pi \sqrt{\frac{r^3}{GM}}$.
coreConcepts.example: This confirms Kepler's 3rd Law ($T^2 \propto r^3$).
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: Orbit showing one full period.

sections.title: Energy of an orbiting satellite
sections.description: Analysis of the kinetic, potential, and total mechanical energy of satellites.

content.introduction: An orbiting satellite possesses both kinetic energy (due to motion) and potential energy (due to position). The total energy determines the orbit's stability.

coreConcepts.explanation: Potential Energy: $U = -\frac{GMm}{r}$. Kinetic Energy: $K = \frac{1}{2}mv_o^2 = \frac{1}{2}m(\frac{GM}{r}) = \frac{GMm}{2r}$. Note that $K = |U|/2$.
coreConcepts.example: KE is always positive, PE is always negative.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: Bar chart comparing magnitudes of KE, PE, and Total Energy.

coreConcepts.explanation: $E = K + U = \frac{GMm}{2r} - \frac{GMm}{r} = -\frac{GMm}{2r}$. The total energy is negative, indicating a bound system. If $E$ becomes zero or positive, the satellite escapes.
coreConcepts.example: To move a satellite to a higher orbit (larger $r$), $E$ becomes less negative (increases), so energy must be supplied (rockets fired).
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: Graph of Energy vs Radius.

summary: $K = \frac{GMm}{2r}$

content.introduction: Satellites are classified based on their orbits. Two critical types for modern technology are Geostationary and Polar satellites.

coreConcepts.explanation: These satellites orbit the Earth with a period of 24 hours, matching Earth's rotation. They appear stationary from the ground. Conditions: Orbit must be equatorial, height $\approx 35,800$ km, moves West to East.

sections.title: Weightlessness
sections.description: Understanding the phenomenon of weightlessness in orbit and free fall.

content.introduction: Astronauts in the ISS appear to float. This is not because there is no gravity (gravity is actually quite strong there), but because they are in a state of free fall.

coreConcepts.explanation: We feel weight due to the normal reaction force ($N$) from the ground. If the ground falls away at the same rate we do, $N=0$. In a satellite, both the ship and the astronaut accelerate towards Earth at $g'$. Equation: $mg' - N = ma$. Since $a = g'$, $N = 0$.
coreConcepts.example: Similar to the feeling in an elevator when the cable snaps and it falls freely.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: Free body diagram of a person in a falling elevator showing N=0.

coreConcepts.explanation: True weight is $mg$ (gravitational force). Apparent weight is the reading on a weighing scale ($N$). In orbit, true weight exists (gravity provides centripetal force), but apparent weight is zero.
coreConcepts.example: Objects don't fall relative to the ship; water forms spheres due to surface tension without gravity to flatten it.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: Astronaut floating inside a capsule.
